content:
Posted: February 18
												TL;DR  Lots of fun. Skill required. Totally multiplayer oriented. Recommended.This is definitely the best RTS I have ever played. The game itself is really well balanced. Multiplayer provides you with countless possiblities of destroying other players what appears to be way more entertaining than fighting AI. MoW:AS2 is meant to be played on multiplayer, that's why the skirmishes are so poor in content. What I find to be really interesting about MoWAS: - Stealth, you can generaly hide one of your soldiers in the bushes, waiting for the enemy tanks to approach and immediately destroy at least one of them using AT grenades. The enemy won't be able to spot you without using his own infantry. That's what makes the game feel like a real combat experience. Tanks will always be in need of support, otherwise the enemy will be able to ambush them with ease. - Micromanagement, every unit has a certain amount of ammunition. They can quickly run out of it so you need to make sure that they have got a steady source of ammo. In multiplayer you can simply call a resupply truck which will fully automatically replenish ammunition of your soldiers. Simple, but makes the game way more difficult. - Direct control, you can take control of every single unit that is available in the game. If you feel like you want to do something yourself - do it. It's simple as that. - Destructible environment, not much to say. You can turn every single building into ruin.  - Unit accuracy and damage, I love the way developers programmed that part of the game. Units deal high damage depending on their distance between them and their enemy, so it's really easy to build a line of defence which can't be simply rushed.  - Great vehicle armour mechanics, every vehicle has it's armour. Some are thick, some are not. In MoWAS you need to learn which tanks are going to be destroyed by 76mm gun and which ones require some more firepower. It took my hours to understand what are my tanks capable of.Things that I find annoying or poorly made: - Singleplayer, it basically does not exist. There are skirmishes, but it's nothing interesting in them. - Pathfinding, if you order your troops to run to a certain position then sometimes they might take the longest possible route. - Projectile penetration, sometimes a panzerfaust projectile might get stuck in bale of wheat, you know - standard stuff.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been playing the closed beta since release date and after 3 patches its looking much better...Overall its a big improvement over Assault Squad 1 with the main differences being visual quality and the interface.The use of much newer shaders and multi cpu core support has improvewd the game to a huge degree.. IMHO anyways...The AI seems much smarter and this may be a benefit of multi core support as everyting isnt being computed by just one cpu core ( This is the first game in the series to utilises more than 1 CPU core )Due to the better performance everything seems much quicker and smoother and more realistic....New vehicle models look much cleaner and more detailed with the new 3D models and shaders...I have noticed the following improvements that some might see as trivial but overall they make for a better game... IMHO- Vehicle crews board and unboard vehicles more quickly....- Grenade throws are quicker ( in manual control mode anyway )- Vehicle crews will look for a nearby repair kit if they are told to repair a vehicle and repair kit is not in vehicle...- Ammo out icon for soldiers is great.....- Vehicle damage icon is great...- Vehcile reloading icon on sqaud icon is great..-  New squad icons that show individual soldiers health status is also great.- Inventory exchange bug crash from all previous games is  fixed...- Transferring ammo between vehicles is less likely to result in the two vehicles crashing into each other.- Mortar crews move a bit faster when told to move with the mortar.- Mortar AI seems better, You can now use a sniper or officer with binoculars to spot targets and the mortar will engage more wi;;ingly.- Repairs are quicker.- Grouped soldiers / squads move more smoothly and try to keep the original placement in the squad ( rough formation ) when told to move.- Dying / death animaytions seem more varied and more realistic..- Soldiers loose their helmets less than previous games... ( no more constanty picking up helmets micro managment )- Transferring ammo to a whole squad from a dead soldier or ammo crate is more intelligent,  it gives the correct ammo to the correct soldier ( in most cases ) based on the weapon they are carrying. ( and doesn't crash the game like MOW and AS1 did.. )- Mine laying seems quicker..- Steam workshop support is a great feature because it will make sharing content easy for everyone..All of my observations are from playing single player missions only and don't reflect the Multi player / Cooperative modes of the game....

												As an RTS gamer, I expected this game to be similar to Company of Heroes or StarCraft. I was so very wrong.((I came into this game with no experience of MoW 1))Pros-Excellent selection of units; and when there isn't something there, there's a mod for that.-Large-scale battles-Lots of micro required-Reasonable tutorial level-Level creationCons-Selecting a group of units can be finicky-Lots of micro required (it's a love/hate relationship)-Lag spikes are easily enough to crash a good PC (can be said for most RTS therefore isn't really a complaint)All in all, good game. I won't comment on price because Steam Sale is a thing. 7/10, would recommend.

												If you've played Men of War: Assault Squad 1, you won't find any surprises here. Some new art assets, but no new gameplay or differing modes.Most of the maps are directly lifted from AS1.So is the interface....i think the maps are even listed in the same order.As with the first, you can individually complete the skirmish maps, but there is no campaign to speak of, and no attempt is made to link the map you just finished with the following one.I really enjoyed the original Assault Squad and happily clicked my way through its map list, it was new and fresh...by the end of the list, however, I was happy it was over. The missions are formulaic and tedious.I'm 4 maps into Assault Squad 2 and I'm already tired of the forumula.(holding out for reinforcements while being able to order as many tanks and troops as I like doesn't even make sense)I'm not sure what I was expecting, but this just seems a stale reinterpretation of Assault Squad 1.Wait for a $5 sale.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Men of War:Assault Squad 2 is the most INDEPTH rts I've seen in my entire life.    For someone looking to experience an authentic World War II RTS, this game is for you. The developers at Digitalmindsoft have been blessed by the PC gods and have managed to bestow us this masterpiece. Why do I like this game so much? I think one of the major selling points was the GARGANTOUS range of options. I am specifically referring to the mouth watering stash of firearms, light tanks, medium tanks, HEAVY tanks, fighter planes, destroyers(big boats) and the diverse types of ammunition that accompany them. Not convinced yet? Then take a look at the cover system in place, allowing the player to cleverly place infantry so that they can take advantage of their surroundings. But forget all that. Who even cares if you can control every freaking infantry, vehicle, and weapon known in this game? Who cares if you can dump 20 hours of playing time just in the editor mode making crazy scenarios and reenacting battles? If you're not convinced by now, then my words haven't done the game justice. Check it out for yourself if you won't take my word. Chances are, you'll be as impresssed as I was and still am.LAST BUT NOT LEASTIf you're going to play multiplayer, bring some lube.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												Monetized content by DMS, removal of dissenting comments, not a company worth supporting.  As for the game itself, it's a men of war game which come from a long line of men of war - faces of war - soldiers games which thankfully wasn't managed by DMS.  The skirmish battles are uninspired and reptitive with essentially 3 map templates repeated over across multiple maps.  You have your generic attack missions, your generic defense missions, and lastly your generic 'stealth' assault missions.  They all have the same templates which makes playing a seperate map feel like deja vu all over again.  Generic patrol gets ambushed, go repair and steal the tank before the first enemy wave arrives, etc..  Group of tank in the middle is always present in the "stealth" missions which doesn't require stealth at all nor proper extraction of any but one unit.  As there's no real story mode or any sense of progression, you're just left switching from one template to the same exact template with just a scenary change.The only real saving grace is there are mods as there's always been, and modders can actually make decent maps.

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												I've played MOWAS2 Both ways, with friends, versus, and singleplayer. Therefor, I can tell you the best of both-sides.Singleplayer gameplay: The missions in the second MOWAS are an intresting idea, rather then the classic "Move up and capture" system, you are given challenges/difficult side-objectives. Such as, defend the three trench points untill reinforcements, or stealth tasks, or even running out of reinforcements! It's a cool idea, but, it gets old. There are times when you just want to play a classic "Assault and Secure" objective mission, and don't feel like the new stuff. Multiplayer Gameplay: I feel the game is centered on multiplayer. It is a blast to mow down your enemies together, and move up in the bloody battlefields together. But, there are SO MANY PROBLEMS WITH MULTIPLAYER. Example, if a player tabs out of the game, everyones framed will drop about 40-50 frames, it's not just me, it's everyone I've played with. And, if you're un-lucky, they won't restore to your normal frame-rate. Plus, if you have a bad ping, it will also reduce frames for everyone else. It's really annoying, and they really need to fix it.Preformance: Men of War: Assualt Squad 2 is so horribly optimized. No-matter what GPU You have, or how many gigs of RAM you have, no matter what you do, you cannot escape the horrible FPS Drops. Singleplayer AND Multiplayer. The explosions of ANYTHING, molotovs, vehicles, or even buildings can freeze/crash your game, or make your frames drop severly. I know it's only a beta, and that's why I'm trying to keep my paitence. But, it sometimes get's unplayable. Something they need to fix PRONTO.Overall outcome: I think MOWAS2 has awesome potential, the awesome new graphics, and relieving bug fixes from the first, really make you get excited for new updates. But, the game is not worth the price it has. For a un-optimized, partially buggy, FPS Dropping beta, $30, $20, or even $15 is WAY Too much. I'd say maybe $10 for the BETA. And I will do a review on the offical release of the full game.Minor/annoying bugs: The bugs in MOWAS2 Are small, but really annoying. Example, your tanks won't always shoot at the targets that are most vital, example, I was playing as the Soviet Union, and a Panther was grinding my Infantry, and my T-34, rather focus on the Panther, focused on infantry. Luckily, you can press "E", and take manual control of your units, (Also needs work), you can take out yourself, annoying, but playable. That's really it for the bugs.Final Verdict: I'll give MOWAS2 a 6/10, Great potential, but needs tons of work.Since that was Early Access, it's time for the whole game.MOWAS2 In my opinion is a train-wreck of, BS Tank penetration, re*tarded path finding, awful voice acting, and most of all, LAG LAG LAG AND MORE LAG.Gameplay: MOWAS2's Gameplay is alright. Rather then the traditional "Unit" engine, the game runs off of indiviual men in a squad. For example, unlike in other strategy games, you can split off other single men to preform tasks, like, if there is a Tiger coming down the road, you can sneak a guy in the building to the side, and AT 'Nade it, or, if there is a squad, killing yours, sneak an SMG over and wreck the entire squad from one guy behind. This may sound awesome, but it has ALOT of flaws. Example, the faction balance is horrible. Germany and U.K are just stupidly overpowered. While the United Kingdom had♥♥♥♥♥♥takes in WW2, they beat ♥♥♥♥ing EVERYTHING. It's un-realistic. And downright annoying. They have huge armor, and for some reason, the guns devistate anybody. Tiger, to an M20. They will get 1-hitted.Gameplay: Tanks: The tanks in the game can be really fun, or really annoying. Even though you have the ablility to press "E" And take control of any man/unit in the game, it still feels very unfinished. The aiming, ecspeically in tanks is really really REALLY hard. The gun never fires at the right thing, but over/under it. And meh, just dosent' feel very nice. The tanks for America are SO underpowered. I know that they had horrible armor, But even the pershing seems UP. Like, a f*ucking 2Pndr AT Gun can 1-Hit a Sherman. A 2 POUNDER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Sorry. I get kinda♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at this game cause it has such great potential, but just dosen't go reach it's hight of glory. German tanks are okay. They could be better. But, meh. They're playable. The Soviet Union's tanks are pretty BS OP as-well. A T-34 57 can One-hit anything. A tiger, to a jeep. It's screwed. Japan's tanks are♥♥♥♥♥♥ But, it's how it was.Gameplay: Infantry: Infantry isn't really a problem in MOWAS2, They're pretty balanced. Actually, very balanced. Vehicles seem to ruin the fun play of infantry. Having a fierce fire-fight? It'd be a shame if a tank just ran everyone over. I don't really have much to say about this. Gameplay:Multiplayer: This is what ruins MOWAS2. Though, there are single-player missions in the game, the missions are crap though, as said in my Pt. 1 in my review, but, the multiplayer in MOWAS2 can be really fun, if you don't have the FRAME DROPS AND THE LAG SPIKES ALL THE TIME! I swear, if you dare, DARE tab out, or anybody tabs out, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥torm of FPS drops, timeouts, and frustration. And, the game seems to drop FPS randomly. Not a massive problem. The game is very well optimised. And it's nice to play even on low.I really can't be bothered to make a huge Pt.2, due to the fact that I could go on for days. Final Verdict, of Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a 4/10 Awful Strategy game.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												I know that a lot of people are saying that this game is a copy of the first assault squad. The 2 have some similarities, but there are also some differences.The units and tanks do look the same. They have added a few units but not very many. I know that this game is a sequel, which means that the game should be similar, but this game looks REALLY SIMILAR. Pros:-The game has pretty good gameplay and quite a few levels.-The game is very addictive.-There are many different types of units and countries to play as.-There are probably 50 different tanks, and each one feels very different from the others.Cons: -This game is bascially a reskin of the first one. Some of the maps are nearly identical, and many of the units are the same.-This game has some of the worst voice acting that I have ever heard. Since when did German field commanders have American accents?-This game is too expensive when compared to teh first which is much cheaper and very similar.Summary:Although the game is good, it is basically a copy and paste of the first and seems to be a cash grab. I just picked the first one up and a whole bunch of DLC on sale for $5. Just buy the 1st one and save yourself a lot of money. I give this game a 5/10.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												Men of War Assault Squad 2 - in my opinion the current best (and hardest) RTS game with a  WW2 setting.The game features a lot of missions split up between the 5 different nations. Germany, GB, USA, Japan & Sovjet Russia. While the pattern for the missions is the same they do play entirely different due too the different maps & nations. Defend - attack - defend is what the first mission, more like tutorial mission, is like. Every other mission is either attack or defend. You have to capture outposts, reach waymarks and defend hills & important places. Easy, yet challenging.There is no base building involded - you gain new units via reinforcement points or by capturing enemy tanks. Yes, capturing enemy tanks. Each and every one of your units can be split up, managed individually, forged into a new squad, has his own inventory, can be used with manual aim [...]. Including tanks! Tanks can be used with minimum manpower - the driver only. Or you can fully stack up and even place infantry on the back of the tank for faster movements. Its entirely up to you.You units can switch weapons, ammo & special items, you can loot dead enemies to gain new weapons and ammo [...] the possibilitys are endless.What is the challenging part of all this? Sounds rather nice, doesnt it? The challenging part is the micromanagement, map awareness and realism. Tanks who get to close to trenches full of infantery - one AT grenade to his engine and hes busted. Infantery running over an open field - on mg salvo, all dead. The game does everything right that can be done right - a solid 10/10!

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												This game looks beautiful. But its an unruly beast to control. You are basically controlling a section against companies of enemy, which is OK, but you have your hands full fighting a floating camera, and imbedded menus within a realtime environment where time flows too fast for the micro management involved. Even with pausing and performing actions while paused something seems off. I could buy this game today for $8.97 on a weekend sale, but I wouldn't get much fun out of it having downloaded a 24 hour trial I have determined its not for me. Its a shame they can't  re-vamp this game because it really looks awesome and its a scale of game I typically enjoy.  I've played a few of this series before, like faces of war, men of war 1, in a similar seed but found not much has changed,  too scripted for my liking.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Guess this game is nice if you just want to jump into a match. There is no actual campaign though, which is disappointing. The skirmishes just throw you into a conflict without any regards to knowledge. You can watch YouTube clips for the tutorial. Out of 10 I would give this game a 5. It is good to the point that the tactics are solid, the graphics are nice. The UI could use some work as it isn't clear how to quickly switch from one squad to the next without manually doing it. If there was a campaign with an actual story line that lead to a destination then I would totally buy this game. But I don't have the time to watch all the videos in order to teach myself this game just to play against far superior players. This game feels more like an early access than a complete game due to all the key RTS factors that it doesn't have.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												I've only played a few minutes and i can already respect the people who play this game, but its not my cup of tea.MoW: Assault Squad 2 is a very tecnical game, you need to position troops over a huge map and acomplish multiple objectives in a single stage to achieve victories, the character models are too small and the map is too big, its a dream come true if you have the patience to carefully observe all angles and possible positions for your army, but otherwise its a bit of a nightmare, i dont generally complain about the blessings a game bestows upon us gamers, but this game is a bit too hard to micromanage for normal people.If you love strategy games, this is just like Commando (the old squad strategy game were you had to use only 4 characters to destroy entire german bases), in that winning maps takes minute planning, except in here you get to field an entire army, in much bigger map, which expands as you clear objectives (so you cant plan ahead too much sometimes)Its a great game, its just a bit too much consuming and quite big on micromanaging. I suggest you try it if its still free on steam when you read this review.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												I would really like to give this game a 'thumbs up' but I am quite anooyed at how the devs have released DLC after DLC instead of the FREE UPDATES they promised. The most meaningful 'update' I have seen added the ability for units to auto re-supply. Oh, and they added a tank that is pretty terrible. Apart from that I havent noticed any change in the game since launch. Also, the AI in the game is still terrible, sometimes my AT troops will break cover and run up to a tank and get mowed down, instead of firing the launchers they have. I have over 300hrs on AS1 and to be honest this is the same game with a few new SP missions. On the MP side, I have yet to fully experience it as I have NEVER BEEN ABLE TO JOIN A MULTIPLAYER MATCH. Googling for my problem results in millions of results for 'MOW AS2 Out of sync error'. This issue has still not been fixed for 1000s of people since launch. I feel pretty bad that I convinced my friend to buy this so we could play together only to discover none of us can join any MP matches. The editor is very fun and is where I spend most of my time, but it is almost the same as AS1 in most aspects.HOWEVER, This is still a fun game (if you like spending 3 days to make a decent looking map to have fun battles on against the ai you have to script every move and action for) and this is indicated by my high playtime on both titles. I heard the devs recently added AI to MP mathces (Which should have been a free update not DLC) and from what I hear, it is pretty terrible.Would still play this over COH2 though.verdict (without editor): 4/10            (with editor)      : 6/10            (forgetting multiplayer ever existed) : 8/10

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I only tried the game when it was playable for free for a few days. Not much of a strategy player, yet I HAVE played some in the past, and the problem for me, with this one, was that I was totally lost right away. The mission objectives are quite clear, the UI isn't too cluttered, yet I still didn't know how to actually control my soldiers. I'd try to get some to throw grenades, marked several at once to take out an enemy shooter, etc, and it only worked like a quarter of the time. I'd try all kinds of combinations (left click, mouse click, function keys), yet never was sure whether I am supposed to manage each soldier individually, command a small group, and how exactly to get them to actually do a certain thing. I looked for a tutorial, and all I found was a bunch of short youtube videos linked in game, which didn't help much either.Call me a total idiot, if you like, and no, I didn't try the first MoW. But I think if the developer is trying to get new players to join in this day and age (call it the idiot age where people do like tutorials to learn the controls instead of watching youtube vids or googling for a guide), they might wanna give newcomers some clue on how to actually control your troops correctly, without them having to try by trial and error how to even make a soldier throw a grenade. ANY indicator would help.

Early Access Review
								703 Hours of playing Men of war Assult Squad 1. After playing 2, I noticed right away that theres no reload option for my units. Infact there are less options all around. You can imagine for a player who enjoys absolute control this was quite a let down. I also noticed that the company icons look alot like company of heros unit icons. I played the entire first mission through the Americans and to my suprise after capturing 2 flags i still couldn't recruit a morter team nor could I recruit an mg team and when i recruited a ranger team instead of coming in a half track like they usually do they came on foot. Im greatly frusterated because to me in feels like they have gone backwards and taken away more then improved it. As a devoted fan there are many things already about this game that really make it feel like company of heros 2. If you were to ask me if you should buy this i would definitly wait for it to be finished, im extremely unhappy about what iv'e seen as of now.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								I played th Beta, and the second skirmish misson for the U.S. is completely broken. Towards the end, you have to get to an extraction point. Simple enough, except it's guarded by an anti-aircraft gun that can see you for miles, and you can't get close enough to take it out. There are three tanks in the level, but the game won't let you take them. You also, have a fixed amount of points, and when I got to the end of the level, I was only able to call in Officers (They literally can't do anything), a single medic (slightly less useless at the point I was at), and snipers (Very useful normally). Funnily enough, it's impossible to shoot off the gunner from the front, and there's no spot I could get to that was behind it, or to the side of it. On top of that, tanks continued to spawn, making the situation worse. If I'm buying a game from you, I should actually be able to play it, instead of just losing, almost automaticly. I'm serverly dissapointed, especially since when I bought it, there were numerous games on sale, invluding the ENTIRE rockstar collection. I could've bought half of them for the same price of this game, but I liked the first Assualt Squad, and was so excited for this one, I wanted to get a little cheaper, and make sure I got it. To summarize, broken level, automatic failure, frustration, anger.

												The Men of War series is one of my favorite PC games ever. This installment is just a polished MoW Assault Squad I, rereleased with a few extra bells and whistles. On sale, it's worth $10-$20, and if you're a fan of the series than it's worth a little more. It's RTS, squad-control, and micro-management to the extreme. I love being able to control a whole squad, or tank, all the way down to a single infantry man who can pick up a dropped grenade, ammo clip, or check a fallen soldiers inventory. I recommend it for fans of Dawn of War II, CoH's, and the Total War series.

												This game is perfect for all you war nuts and RTS fans out there. If you looked at this game and thought it would be fun, get it, it is. This game strikes a fantastic balance of macro and micro managing, from telling a group of soldiers to take cover to manually controlling a tank. The detailed visuals and sounds just add so much to an already amazing game. If you have ever played "Close Combat" or similar games you will love this game. The feeling you get when you drop a 600mm (23.6 inches to fellow americans) diameter Rocket on several tanks blowing them several meters into the air and then watching the wreckage rain down from the sky is amazing.

												First off, let me begin by stating that I purchased the complete edition of this game when it was on sale for $10. If you already have the original Men of War: Assault Squad, I don't reccomend buying this game for full price. Wait until it goes on sale and grab the complete edition. Alright, now that I've gotten that out of the way, let me begin my review. :)This game is awesome, and for RTS lovers, a must buy. The detail is great and the options for battlefield tactics are unlimited. I haven't played a RTS that handles combat as well this does. If you're a Star Wars fan, get the Galaxy at War mod. It'll completely blow away the land battles in Empire at War. Lastly, this game runs very well on my laptop. I have a Nvidia GeForce GT 640M (1GB Dedicated GDDR5) and I'm getting 60+ fps with little action and 30+ when the fighting is heavy on medium settings. Overall I reccomend this game to all RTS lovers.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Background: Having just come off of 150 hours on Company of Heroes 2 this game kicked my butt. Like seriously there are not many games that I review that I highly recommend to Follow the Tutorials to the T.  I also never played the First one or the HD Remake of the First One.The Take on Realism: You have to worry about ammo, medkits, and form infantry columns that are able to tackle a variety of situation from assaulting in CQC or disabling Armor. Repairing damaged vehicles actually takes Real Time Minutes to complete. Individual units within your formations can be targeted and taken out. Nothing is safe out there. On easy difficulty I found myself overwhelmed sometimes with Management that a single MG can pin you down and seal the deal.  To add to this each unit has its own manageable inventory. Like a single rifleman will have 250 .30-06 rounds on him, his M1 Garand, Helmet, Shovel, and maybe a grenade. Your Russian officer will have a pistol, 70 rounds, officer hat. Don’t worry equipment can be transferred between units.This realism also extends to Line of Sight Mechanics. Most RTS we are used to our units having to rely on sight lines combo’d with a set Range they can fire. Well with this game, your tank can literally shoot in whatever direction if your mouse lets you. So go nuts, shoot across 3 wheat fields into the dirt if you’d like. (See Armor Mechanics below for your True Ranges)Note: they do give us one freebie with Ammo management and that is a single 8 man unit that you form by mouse dragging Automatically Shares Ammo.  This is great because you can click on one man run him to the ammo truck, load him up with 5000 rounds, run back to the defensive line, rejoin him to a unit and bam, the entire unit is rearmed. The Campaign: There are a nice array of factions to play. Though the campaign is a Copy Paste for each faction, it gives you a great way to learn each Faction’s strengths and weaknesses to ultimately prepare you for Online Matchmaking.  The Campaign Scenarios are actually built well to teach you LOS, Direct Unit Control, Defense of an objective, Flanking, Sniping, Armor Control and Field Guns. Direct Control: There are a few other games I have seen in recent years that allow Direct control over units within an RTS.  There are a couple on Steam but I fail to remember their names.  Direct control happens in a 3rd person Top Down view. Note that this is a Single Unit. A Single Man, a Single Tank, etc. In this mode you control all aspects of the Unit, aiming with mouse and movement that you can modify to be the Arrow keys or WASD. I highly suggest getting used to this mode as it is invaluable at all difficulty levels. Direct control of a tank is superior in all ways and will help you survive online and in the Scenarios.Armor Mechanics: I’m going to distill this down to as simple as I can. Scoring a hit on any Vehicle is factored in by a number of ways. Your unit has armor penetration values applied at 3 different ranges. This is to say how much armor it can penetrate at a given distance. This is then compared against glance values and Armor Values of the Target to determine if the shot glances off with a visual market, or penetrates the Armor and scores a hit. Now in addition to kill hits, there are track hits that cause you to be unable to move and turret hits which cause you to be unable to rotate the turret. To add to this you have ammo types that can modify their target values and properties. HE for Infantry, AP which you have very few of for Armor Busting, and general shells.  Armor values are also generally weaker on the sides and rear.What all this means is that your angle, gun values, and range all factor into your success in Armor vs Armor fights. What this also means is that if you’re going up against some heavy Panzers in light British armor you’re going to have a bad day if you don’t Flank immediately. Infantry Mechanics: Infantry can be given 3 positions, standing, crouching, and prone. They are outfitted for their role on the field as general Riflemen, Snipers, AT crew, Tank Crews, and various Specialty units per each faction. Gun accuracy values are compared to the target’s use of cover and range from your position to determine hit factor. When you direct control a snipe get used to being able to quickly identify enemy AT carriers, it’ll make your life 10 times easier. Final Thoughts: If you can survive the super realism (On the scale of video games) and the micromanagement aspects. Then this is the WWII Simulator for you. However if you are on the fence about RTS in 2016 and want a more straight forward more forgiving game then I highly suggest Company of Heroes 2.As Always watch gameplay videos before buying!

Posted: August 30, 2015
												This game like all the other Men of War games is a complete master piece!This game isnt to much of a change from Men of War: Assault Squad 1, but there are some small things that make it that much better. 1: Graphics are a bit better and some bug fixes (some)2: Better units. Example: In the mission Overlord for the americans, when calling in paratroopers a squad of 5 parachutes in, instead of just one trooper, this is a major fix in my mind, logically you would send 1 trooper in at a time and sending in squads would be a more "rational" amount. 3: MAJOR FIX: mulitplayer is fixed and you can play online, unlike the other Men of War: Assault Squad that ran off of game spy (an unused and discontinued gaming network). This makes the game so much better, multiplayer, for players who has friends that don't own the game, or those who don't have friends (if you don't have any, make some!)4: This isn't a fix but makes the game so much more fun, Steam Workshop, custom maps easier to get and mods the same! There are some great maps and mods on the workshop and i recommend anyone that has to check it out!This game get a 10/10 for the beautiful and never ending fun that the game gives!

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												This game makes me hate two specific groups of people.  First: big game developers who prove once again that by throwing heaps of money at promotion (I’m looking at you CoH 2) their game can outperform superior games.  And second, people who aren’t willing to put in the effort to learn a new game because it’s hard.  There is no question that MOWAS II is a thinking man’s game.  To be good you have to know armor values, penetration chances, gun calibers, and much more.  You have to invest your points in the right units, know how to use cover, and give your troops good lines of sight.  One mortar shell will kill and entire squad if you bunch them up behind a sandbag because, well, that’s reality.  Remember that veteran tiger that you saved up all game for?  You didn’t support it with infantry so it died to one AT grenade in less than 2 minutes.   It’s not CoH 2, or rather a glorified game of rock, paper, scissors, you actually have to think.  I already know people will say ‘yeah that’s all well and good but who has the time to learn all that?’ and it’s a weak argument.  If you’re going to invest a day of your life into a game anyway what is another five or six hours to learn how to play it well? The point it this is a fantastic game.  Take the time to learn it and come have some fun.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is probably the worst gay porn I’ve played. Though it looks exciting and sounds fun, and moves hard and rapidly, it rarely gets me off.People have been saying that THIS entry in the series is supposed to be the multiplayer, coop one. And I (usually) love watching guys tongue each other’s♥♥♥♥♥♥♥with my friends just like everyone else does. But what if I told you that the American scenes in this collection are basically the same as the German ones, which are basically the same as the Japanese ones, which are basically the same as the British ones, and the Russian ones? All five of the nations. What if I told you that the sniper (or optionally commandos) scene for the U.S. is repeated four times with the other nations? And also the same for the defense scenes? And also the advance-across-the-set scenes? What if I told you that instead of the 40, original group sex scenes advertised on this store page, you get, actually, just 8 that are (arguably) original? And now, forget the what ifs; because it’s true.These 15 and 25 scenes are actually just eight. Different actors for each nation? Sure. But the interracial variety isn’t enough. What about the Steam Workshop mods? Well I played two of the top-rated ones, SirHinkel’s AS2 Missions and RobZ’s Base Defense ones. And they do suck♥♥♥♥♥ but not in a good way.SirHinkel’s missions are his interpretations of famous man-on-man actions, including a very well-realized The Alamo orgy, from the epic gay porn film Saving Private Ryan. And though Italian and Hungarian men join the action during SirHinkel’s Stalingrad orgies, they’re almost all just long slogs. You can certainly set the intensity of the boning (Easy, Medium, etc.), but instead of more exciting moments of drama, you usually get merely longer scenes. And sure some people like long, hard sex scenes before the actors get so tired that, finally, they all just exhaustedly come onto each other’s throbbing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ But let’s be real: the best gay porn follows the quality-over-quantity standard. SirHinkel DID put a lot of strategic thought into his scenes, with many good placements for many dangerous toys, but as for the great climactic moments, when you just want to ejaculate while the actors do: well, they rarely happen, and (strangely) they usually do so near the beginning of his scenes. So it’s just hours of repetitive hard ♥♥♥♥ing, until it’s finally, suddenly over.As for RobZ’s base defense scenes, you look at their descriptions and think you’re in for a really good time. You start playing one and lay your initial men in comfy spots, waiting for the other nation’s uniformed-men to creep up and come on them. But it’s all ruined by what must be two bugs. Specifically: when you call in more of your dudes to join the orgy, they (infuriatingly) WALK, and unenthusiastically. And on top of or under that: these men will change their destination to wherever you tell the next boys you call in. So you have to manually look at the troops as they walk onto the scene and jerk them into running to where you actually want them. And on large set pieces, where the defenses are far from where you call in the new boys, it Just Makes Masturbation a Chore, as you move the screen across the map, clicking the walking unit, moving across the map to where you really want them, double right-clicking that spot so they run to THAT SPOT, repeat... No gay porn should soften one's♥♥♥♥♥♥this much...And what about the player-on-player multiplayer? Is it fun to jerk-off with someone across the Internet, or with your friend next to you? Not compared to the Company of Heroes multiplayer it isn't. MoW:♥♥♥♥♥Sqd 2 favors realism too much, and doesn’t understand something important about gay porn (or porn in general): Realistic Sex is not what we want to watch. I mean, for realism just go do the real thing. In pornography you want to see lots of herculean men doing all kinds of crazy♥♥♥♥♥♥to each other’s holes. It’s called FANTASY sex. This understanding is shown by Relic in their Company of Heroes (Vanilla edition). Men of War: Assault Squads 1 and 2 go too realistic, and thus make for undramatic man-on-man "action," over and over and over.In conclusion: for gay, WW2-themed cream pies and facials, play Company of Heroes instead. (I haven’t played Company of Heroes 2; feel free to comment if you have an opinion about its♥♥♥♥♥♥♥rubbing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥action)

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												It might be fun, but I'll never know. There is literally no help learning to play the game. There are some hints that give you strategies or tell you about a specific feature or two, and there is a library of YouTube videos which all explain some of the more complex tasks, but there is no tutorial, introduction, sandbox, or anything like that: you're on your own, and it's trial-and-error. That wouldn't be so bad if the game were a simplistic shooter or a more traditional Age-of-Empires-style RTS: you could guess at the controls and probably get them right enough to play. This, however, is an incredibly in-depth game with a lot of micromanagement that gives you no information about how to find or use its features. It's also a strange combination of realism (various systems on armour which can all be disabled, various weaponry with unique stats and ballistics, etc.) and absurdism (a Thompson with a range of 50 meters, 10+ hits to kill a person, etc.). Like so many others, this game completely ignores the most significant part of a game: teaching the player how to play it. If you have nothing else to do, or if you enjoy spending most of your time reading about your new game rather than playing it, you can probably learn Men of War: Assault Squad 2 in a couple days. Otherwise, skip it and wait till the publisher gets serious.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Here's the deal:This game is identical in almost every aspect to the first MoW: AS. The maps are identical, the controls are identical, the UI is (mostly) identical, etc. However, the first AS is very old. If you're like me you put hundreds of hours into it by now and have probably even stopped playing it because you've done everything there was to do. I was at that point with the first one and hadn't opened it up in over three months because I was tired of it, until I saw this go on sale for 60% off. I figured "Hey, what the hell, I get the full deluxe edition for $15 and I will be able to play Assault Squad again even if it's the same damn game." As long as you know going into it that this is just an updated version of the first one, you will be fine and enjoy it. Do not expect anything new from the single player aspect other than a couple UI changes and (somewhat) better voice acting. The voice acting in the first one was so terrible though it wasn't hard to improve on. The only real changes are the focus on Steam and multiplayer. Steam Workshop means this game will stay fresh for a very long time with new content from users and it has all the bells and whistles of modern Steam games like cards to collect, XP to earn, in-game achievements to show off, etc. The other noticeable change is the difficulty level. Remember how ridiculously hard the first AS was on Hard mode? I literally rage quit dozens of times because the difficulty level was ABSURD. This game.. not so much. The Hard mode feels like Normal mode from AS. Heroic here is basically Hard mode there. This is a good thing in my opinion because it now allows hardcore fans like me to earn Heroic achievements because they were unattainable in the first. I wouldn't even try Heroic mode in the original one because I figured the AI had pocket nuclear missiles and a time machine to warp stealth fighters and gauss cannons back to beat my♥♥♥♥♥with. If you ever completed the single-player campaign from AS on Heroic mode, you should write a book about your endeavor and send me a copy. TL;DRUpdated version of the first game. Difficulty turned down a few notches. Get this on sale and don't expect a whole new game.

Posted: October 11, 2014
												UPDATE 22/02/2014The game has been transformed in some kind of test ape for DMS future product: Call of Arms. Features, which have little or no benefit for MOW, are rushed in a pre-alpha status and they have completely broken the game. Many people can not start the game, most of the people are suffering frequently crashes. Finishing a 2v2+ game is impossible.After one year from release the game fundamentals, like stability and lag, are still broken and nothing let us think they will be fixed. I waited one year in the hope that items for which the game was sold would be fixed. But this is the status today:- steam integration (to start the game you have to deactivate steam overlay)- improved graphics ( maybe a little on some machine)- steam multiplayer (broken)- matchmaking (broken)- 8v8 on spectacular maps( no 8v8 on sight and maps are the same as 5 years ago also they changed the store page to 4v4)My opinion over the gameplay remains unchanged: when played the game is fun, but currently it just can't be played therefore I don't feel like suggesting to buy it, it has no future.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												Great Game. In its current stage, however, it is buggy and clunky. It has potential, but I would currently recommend COH2 over this game simply because of gamplay. For one, the AT guns (on all sides) are not very functional. I was in a game with a friend and the guns literally wouldn't fire at any of the tanks. Furthermore, when I ordered them to fire, they ran outside the house they were in, straight into machine gun fire. All of them were killed. If the creators fixed game mechanics, I would definitely buy into it. Second, the level up system is bullcrap. Just give the players access to all units. It just makes no sense to me why you wouldn't do that --- this is a strategy game, so why throw in random crap that casual players may never get to? Overall the game is just clunky and feels incomplete --- fix those problems, and I'll buy into it. Regardless, this game is still ok. I would recommend most steam users hold off and wait till it's cheaper, however.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Game is very strategic and skill based. The single player is kind of lack luster but it makes up for it in the multiplayer. Some things that are unique are the direct control feature where you can control your units movements and gun. You can do this on any unit in the game and it really dodges any problems you would have with Ai not going exactly where you want them or shoot where you want. Vehicle fighting is fun because they don't just have a health bar, they have components on them that can be damaged and need to be repaired. When fighting a heavy tank that your gun can't pin, if you flank around the side of it you might be able to pin through the weaker side armor, it adds a very fun game mechanic. It does require a lot of micro but that is part of the fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												After a few patches this game without mods became much better than the first Assault Squad in terms of gameplay and visuals.At first it looked like a generic copy of the first game but with a couple of added missions and extra fancy variables however, this game now looks worth buying at full price, the amount of new missions is incredible, the scripting for the missions have improved greatly.The maps don't look much different to the first Assault Squad however, the new textures for units and new vehicles make the game look so much different. The SS soldiers now wear realistic M44 Peadot Camouflage and British Commandos with proper Pattern 2 Denison Smocks. The skins for the vehicles look much nicer on top of that and the veterancy system for each individual unit is a nice mechanic.The multiplayer is also as enjoyable as the first Assault Squad, even more so with the great modding community behind the game, AS:2 has a workshop which AS did not. Now my mods can automatically update to keep up the game's patches and developer's work without me having to keep going back to websites such as ModDB to see what's new and spend hours reinstalling.Overall I would recommend this game to anyone, new or old comers to the Men of War Franchise as the game offers so much and the rewards and achievements are plenty.

content:
Posted: April 18
Men of War Assault Squad 2 is an rts game that has touched a part in me that no other games apart from Call to arms that has never really come that close. As a teenager I used to make models using Airfix and once when I was 12/13 years of age I built a model in school from using paper mache. The model representing a typical no mans land of World War 1. I constructed the map on a large oblong wooden board. I used matchsticks for designing the wooden floors inside trenches and very thin wire scrunched up for a barbed wire effect with painted matchsticks that would ideally serve as wooden poles for keeping the barbedwire together creating an appropriate realism. When I would take the model home I would sit there for hours repositioning my plastic soldiers and vehicles that I had bought or made using Airfix. The fun times I had then thinking back now makes me realise much more how grateful I am to own such a wonderful creation in my games library. My imagination then as a teenager is exactly the same now as when I build my maps for the Men of war Assault  Squad 2 Workshop. As I always get that exact same blueprint thrill now as I did when I was much younger. The best part about Men of War Assault Squad 2 is the Steam Community Workshop. The amount of goodies on there is basically a gamers paradise for updating their MOWAS2. Think of it like this.If the games updates suddenly ceased on the developers side, well the Steam Workshop carry on the updating process for many years to come like the new generation of gamers say 20/30 years from now. I always like to think how my workshop maps being still appreciated by the future generation of new gamers to the growing compilation of Men of War. Also the whole point of the Steam Workshop is that the modifications there is a great contribution for keeping Men of War Assault Squad 2 alive & strong for many years to come as they serve as updates for the game anyway. Check out the Steam Workshop here http://steamcommunity.com/app/244450/workshop/Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a game that has saved me so many times when wanting to feel that old feeling again as I did when building my models as a teenager all those years ago. As I said up there no other game has ever really come that close.Thank You so much to Digitalmindsoft for creating a masterpiece that will always serve its place in the priceless treasure trove of classsic rts games.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												This game is both the best ww2 title out there and the worst disaster of a game at the same time.  It holds some great game elements as well as some absolute game design disasters. It is sad to see so much potential getting wasted.First, the good stuff:Let me begin by saying this: After playing this game for a bit, other titles like Company of Heroes really started to look like jokes.Both infantry and armor gameplay are awesome.The multiplayer game experience in itself is awesome. No other words for it. It has a very good tempo. The stakes are always high. So much can change in a split second. The balance between infantry and armor is top notch. The arcade element is there and it rewards good play. The best part is, this game is doing all this while keeping a very good amount of realism and detail.All the factions that the game comes with. Like, really. I see so many people complaining about AI not being free. Ok maybe thats wrong but you guys realize that this is pretty much one of the few ww2 titles that comes with five factions right? Thats gotta mean something.The mod support. There are mods featuring even the tiniest of ww2 factions. Wanna play as french in 1940? you got it. Would you prefer to play as Poland? Sure thing! You want the game to be much more spectacular and realistic? Tired ot the games linear and unimaginative skirmishes? Do you want to play with star wars factions? Hell, do you want a mod of a weeb anime about schoolgirls and tanks? You have it all. With all the mods there are out there, the vanilla game feels like a mere demo of the full experience. And make no mistake, the vanilla game still has a lot of content.Yeah, it sounds awesome right, Now for the bad stuff:Multiplayer matchmaking system. It's not just bad, it practically doesn't exist. You don't have any way to just hop in and play, you have to host a game, wait for people to join in (which takes so much as 20 minutes sometimes) and you have no idea if they are in your level or not. It can be a nice competitive match or just an absolute massacre. This is the result of trying to implement restricted units and having downright unimaginative stupid map designs for current ingame matchmaking system. A game like this shoud have had dedicated matchmaking for individual mods.Too many settings for multiplayer. This is not supposed to be a problem, but when the matchmaking is broken, some people will never learn about the proper balanced settings of the game.The skirmishes are linear and repetitive. If you want good single player content you have to go to the workshop.The difficulty setting of the skirmishes are downright ridiculous. I mean seriously, changing damage infantry takes? I mean how dimwitted you have to be for not realising doing that changes the game's mechanics completely? Being able to run at a mechinegun fire just kills the games experience and gives the beginners wrong expectations about everything. Not to mention that it defeats the whole purpose of having a single player campaign which is primarily educating the player for full multiplayer experience.Infantry animations look cheap. It is the first thing most of the newcomers will notice and it doesn't hold up with the rest of the game.Bugs and out of sync issues. Which is much better by now but having constant out of snyc problems for more than year after the launch is pretty bad. Along with the broken matchmaking, this is the reason why so few people play it today.DLCs are not well thought out. Seriously, mods are better.The developers of this game made a great product but somehow it seems like they don't really understand what makes it so great. And they don't seem to understand some of the most fundamental gamer expectations. All that said, I would still recommend this game. Even with all the dlc's the price is a bloody steal for all the content it provides. BUT keep in mind that its rough around some of the edges that it really shouldn't have been.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Is this game 10 times better than company of heroes?   YESI am soooo tiered of games that the units engage in combat with auto hit system (al la starcraft) so it turns into a health bar drainage with not to hit or miss possiblity. Basically an rts water balloon fight to see what unit counters what and drains health bars quicker than other units as the main focus. The person who click manages the build system is the one who comes out on top usually. None of that here...each unit is spawned based on objectives like coh but more realistic. Each unit has a personal name, gain experience based on performance, and have attritional statistical values that contribute to a hit or miss attack as well as variable damage. Each section of the map is an all encompassing campain, not a region that loads once you arrive there trigering the ai at that monment to take action. THIS GAME IS FANTASTIC ...HOWEVER....Biggest complaint tho with this game....WHY IN THE HELL Do THE UPDATES KILL THE PREVIOUS SAVES!!!EFFECTIVLY THIS GAME IS BROKEN! you will never get through the campain before they pull a mandatory update again one day and render all of your previous saves unreadable! its the single most rediculous thing ever. In fact I dont know a game that does that. But yeah, You will continually have to start from the beginning with the way its set up. loose all your  hard work and experienced units that carry over to the the next fight becuase they dont know how to code the saves to work with new versions of the game once its updated. so you just loose it all!

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I have been quite the fan of Men of War. I love RTS and I love WWII, so its perfect for me. One thing to note is that this game can be incredibly complex. The amount of micro you CAN put into this game can be quite insane. Every single unit has an inventory, ammunition, tanks/vehicles have fuel that runs out. It can all be resupplied from trucks or dead troops or vehicles. This game is tons of fun and extremely realistic. There really isnt much of a singleplayer campaign/story its more of just challenge skirmishes that you can play by yourself or with friends. Do not get me wrong it can be incredibly fun. This game takes time to learn, but it is one of the most rewarding gaming experiances ever. I love it. Here is the difficult thing, it really isnt much of a step up from the first Men of War Assault Squad. Yes they included all the DLC maps that they sold to people in the first one, and there are new units and it handles slightly better than its predecessor but not by much. The game is in need of a new engine badly, the games engine cannot handle how complex the physics are. Other than that if you are aware that it really isnt a sequel but more of an update/expansion? I guess and you know what your getting into then go for it pick it up. Other than that don't buy it unless its on a sale if you have the first.8.5/10

												Its the exact same as Assault Squad 1.  All the same skirmish missions with a few extra added in that are new. Instead I must trudge through the old missions to get to the new.  The other thing I do not like at all about either game is that each skirmish mission for each country is EXACTLY the same format.  A little variety here and there and perhaps a bit more uniqueness when it comes to the different countries would be fantastic.  Things that feature the strengths and weaknesses of a country perhaps.  I just cannot recommend this game but if you do not have either and absolutely want to buy it then do not get both 1 and 2.  As 2 is all you would need and should have been the only one released.  I knew what I was getting to some point but I still feel robbed of my money.

number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was in the main, interested in pre 20th Century warfare and played games accordingly.  Having become very disillusioned with a well known companies latest RTS game which I had been waiting for...for many years, I went out looking for a replacement just to keep me occupied until they got their act together and put it right.  Looking through my old games I resurrected MOWAS1, played a few games and really enjoyed myself.  Then noticed that MOWAS2 was being released in Beta during March 2014, read the blurb and signed up and duly paid my monies for the Deluxe edition...  Since then I have never looked back, I have loved every bit of the 140 odd hours played (that equates to less than £0.15p per hour), and it hasnt even been officially released yet.  Sure there are glitches (still Early Access when writing this post), but they will be resolved. the single play and Co-op has been envigorating and have made many new friends to wile away the hours with.  I highly recommend this game to anyone from a single play and Co-op play perspective (Not really played enough Multiplay to comment).  Bye-the-way, I havent even looked back to see if the ancients RTS game I waited for, has improved......

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												I wish I could recommend this game for it is a totally unique ww2 rts game with all sorts of fun interaction and destroyable enviroments with a whole bunch of different units.It's still a great joy when your tank gets destroyed and the men inside have to get out, now what do you do? You won't win any fight against an enemy tiger with a pistol. But oh wait! you can look inside your tank and take some dynamite out of it. Now just take direct control of your guy and run like a maniac or sneak behind The enemy tank and just place that dynamite right on there and watch the fireworks happen. There is a lot of value in this game if you can look past a lot of issues which are: bad user interface, horrible micro management of your units, sometimes laggy gameplay, even game breaking bugs. And if you play this game without Robz Realism or GSM mod you are going to have a bad time with damage modeling being just plain awful, artillery range being weak like a potato gun and tanks going slower than a snails pace. I really would not recommend playing without one of those mods.Multiplayer works most of The time quite well if players have good internet connection and pc's. It's easy to get matches happening since there are a small community of dedicated players. You can set up all sorts of custom rules for your games too. Since I like to play with Robz Realism modification The online matches can sometimes end in a game breaking bug if you have lots of units that have broken down and created all sorts of clutter and destroyed buildings and so on. I think it's because the game engine was not meant to be designed for that much stuff on the battlefield at once. Luckily this only happens in really large battles and personally I really don't enjoy the kind of games where there is just too much points available to spend on a thirty tanks and fifteen batallions of troops at once.There are a lot of content available for this game but the developers have made patches to The game that render some of The steam workshop content unplayable with The latest version. There are a lot of custom campaigns that can be played in co-op too. You can even find a total conversion that gives The game a modern military theme. I would not recommend bying at full price since I don't think The developers are going to patch this much further anymore.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Played as Nazi Germany, got a 4 - 5 veterancy tank...Saw an achilles.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.. What to do what to do...Tried shooting it, but can't due to it being far...It got the first shot and killed most of the tank crew, two survived the whole match...10/10 Never forget the story of the 4 - 5 veteran tank that almost got destroyed by achilles.Real Review:So Men of War: Assault Squad 2, is about WW2, where you command forces of five factions. Nazi Germany, Japan, Brits, Soviets and Americans. I will say that to get use to this game, you have to learn from other players (Like one of my friends who bought the game recently) or you will be beaten really fast. But playing with a friend will give you really epic moments, like rushing in a zone to kill everyone but get yourself killed, then send in a tank to support the last of your men and capture the point.MOW has a lot of bugs, but can be fixed by getting Robz Realism Mod (Which is really popular) which adds more realism, vehicles and much more. The mods that people make are some of the best ones that i played.Score: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												The developers say Men of War 2? I say Men of War...Again. TL;DR - great game, not a new one though. The latest installment of the Men of War series offers...the same as the first. aside from a few graphical fidelity tweaks, some small mechanic improvementsn and a few additions here and there, i would not title this as anything other than a remaster. All the changes i see in this game couldve been updates for the first, I daren't say it warrants a whole new game. I understand that my hours arent in the hundreds, but after playing the first one and budging myself into buying the second, im not really seeing a difference. At all. I'll keep it short and simple. For those who own the first men of war, you don't gain anything from buying this one. Of course, this game allows multiplayer, as the first one had its servers shut down. But if you're looking for a new singleplayer experience, you won't find it here. It is the same game, with the same missions, and the same features. Some are brushed up a little, but still the same. For those who don't. I would definitely recommend this. it's great, don't be disheartened by the developpers lack of change from the first game. Because the first one was and still is a gem. To summarise, if you're new, go for it. Love the depth of this game and really explore it. If you aren't, save the money, reinstall the first one and be done with it. EDIT: for those of you saying 'IT HAS AN EDITOR THOUGH' yes. It does. correct. But back to my original point, does the addition of an editor really need a WHOLE 'new' release?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												If you love very in-depth WW2 strategy games then you must buy this game. This game's detail to war goes from the stats of a gun, (which you can pick up or throw away) to the thickness of a tank relative to it's placement, and angle. Winning in this game is a fantastic feeling, because there is quite the learning curve. No maybe not control wise, but forgetting to press a button while your troops are advancing can easily get the whole squad killed. This game is easier to learn, and is very difficult to master. Having said that, even I have raged as at some point. It becomes infuriating as you're well thought out troop placements become obsolete when the enemy has an arty piece that for some reason, bull eye's you  almost every time. Rendering your flag with no defense, and all those troop's MP (manpower) cost down the drain. I would say that starting out, play with a friend to learn the controls, then go to public multiplayer to fine tune yourself.That is another thing too that I should add. DO NOT buy this game if you intend to play singleplayer only. This game has a fantastic community and multiplayer system with kind and patient people who are willing to help out first-timers. So be sure to let them help you out. Overall I easily reccommend this game as one of my all-time favorite war games, as I keep coming back to it, over and over again.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												Very good real-time strategy. It reflects the realities of World War 2 Moreover, the fate of the game can change even one soldier I can recommend 100%!Of course, as every game has its pros and cons to mention below.+ Strong emphasis on realism extra game is not easy is quite difficult and you have to toil.+ Extensive vehicles with their damage, destruction, fuel, ammo which changes the very gameplay.+ The ability to use the workshop+ Models destruction and good physics+ A large variety of units.+ Unusual multiplayer games.-Very Unfriendly game for beginners, both in playing the game and in the editor.- Frequent crashes.- Poor optimization of even the most powerful computers strong explosion is able to do the problem computer.-Very Poor singleplayer campaign (fortunately, with the help of steam comes workshop)In my opinion 8/10 because you have to remember that the game is in Beta and is still developing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												One of the best strategy games I have ever played. Being extremely tactical and realistic, it is also quite difficult; even the ammo assigned to each individual soldier is to be kept under control!Tank battles are far more realistic than they are in other similar games; vehicles can be crewed and uncrewed, damages depend on the kind of shell, on the distance from the target and on the hit part. Covers are nice, and it is possible to control the soldiers' stance (standing up, prone and so on) manually. Enemy vehicles, if abandoned and not completely destroyed, can be recovered and stolen. Anti tank guns are really effective against tanks, but there is always a certain amount of randomness which makes everything unpredictable and suspencing. Every action has to be planned accurately, and unreasoned and silly moves are very likely to cause disastrous outcomes; there is a nice reinforcements mechanism which depends on the controlled checkpoints, and new weapons are available on the field after a new checkpoint has been conquered.The only bad thing is that, during multiplayer battles, reinforcements are automatically split among players, causing messy situations ("who called this sniper?" "Can I have your Panzer, or you desperately need it?"). It is possible to send units to an ally player, but this takes time and can be pretty annoying.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												This game is a bit of a conundrum for me. On the one hand I love playing it, and Co-Op is my thing. Using clever tactics and wits to fight your enemies is very gratifying. Online vs. players is wonderful but honestly I just suck too much at it to have a ton fun. On the other hand the AI is LAME, like they spent about 20 minutes on it and decided that since it went places automatically then it was fine. I miss the cool maps and missions of the old Men of War games. Still, because of the entrenched enemies and the constantly annoying reinforcement of tanks and things it’s still challenging to play with online. This game is a ton of fun and I would suggest this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Pros:-Great game and great gameplay-Destruction system(how buildings fall,you can destroy everything to the ground)-Lots of SP missions(even if they are copied versions for all nations) and achievements on every difficulty level-I Love tank/vehicle battles in this game-Experience/level unlock system-Tanks/Antiair 20mm machineguns used on infantry :) they dying like they should not like in other stupid games (CoH)-Damage system is great - tank is a tank not like in company of heroes where squad survives 10 tank cannon shells and    escape to forest,then back after moment and destroying your tank...-5 Nations with lots of different vehicles for all of them :many tanks,AA machineguns,cannons,howitzers,self-propelled howitzers,jeeps,support trucks,stationary machineguns/mortars and many infantry units-Many extra/bonus units for all nations available to call after some time of playing(different for any nation)-Multiple units and especially vehicles makes game a ULTRA interesting for me-Good looking vehicles explosions with flying parts and nice smoke but fire from explosions(in moment when howitzer  shell explode on ground) need to be reworked(looks poor)-Good PriceCons:-MOST IMPORTANT; MATCHMAKING for ranked games not working so new players cant get any place in ladder,cant do some achievements and cant make their stats "fat"...-SP missions need a story : I not need any render movies but even on loading screen there no explanation about the mission,SP need much more  in-game cutscenes in simple words : A REAL STORY with small differences between nations...-MOST IMPORTANT:Game needs extensive statistics not only for ranked games(which not working) but for skirmish with AI too...Anything from those battles not save to stats,only exp and level for nation...I want stats like infantry killed,vehicle destroyed,games won,W/L ratio with AI,same with lost units and even a list How many kills players get in career with all specified vehicles(a list of all vehilces: page per nation with all stats of all vehicles) - because if no advanced stats what is the reason to play game if no friend whos playing this game,ranked games dont work and you dont get anything from playing !?!? I love making my game stats "fat" but in this title nothing saves to those stats except exp and level....-Need more unlocks - dev should add  some camoflauges for vehicles - some different versions snow/desert itc...-Game need a better textures for some infantry models

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												At first I was completely frustrated and thought this game was way too hard to enjoy.  But - once I got the hang of how to use your units together (and keep them stocked with ammo) this became one of the biggest time sucks that's happened at my house in a very long time.  Lots of detail, lots of variety, and the physics system works very well.  As soon as you've taken that victory point, some far-reaching artillery will remind you that what got you here sure as heck won't get you to the next one.  And if you think you'll overpower the enemy with a tank rush, well - just try it.  If Company of Heroes is high school, the MOWAS2 is a graduate degree program. Get it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												I've had this game for a long time and even had some fun with it when I first purchased it but then I drifted back to Company of Heroes 2 as usual. On a whim I fired up MOW AS2 today and had an absolute blast with it. This is a must play for WWII and RTS enthusiasts. It's challenging. Absolute tons of micromanaging to be done here but when you start getting it and making combined arms tactics work it is thrilling. Honestly, it's a difficult game to master and I'm not there yet but if you want a challenge this is your game. The graphics on ultra settings are very very nice and the game's presentation is more "realistic" if I can use that word than Company of Heroes. Performance is a little uneven which is understandable with everything that's going on. It's crazy how many moving parts there are here so a respectable processor is recommended. I have what currently is the flagship AMD APU the A10 7850k OC'ed to 4.5ghz paired with an R9 285 and 32gb of ram (design) and when there's a lot of concentrated artillery, infantry and vehicle movement it can run in the low 20's though I wouldn't say it makes the game unplayable. I probably should mess around with the shadows and post processing to see if I can improve that but for the most part the game runs well. Obviously your experience will vary and if you're on a laptop or older desktop then be prepared to make serious sacrifices in the graphics settings. I should probably mention that there's no proper campaign, it's more a series of disconnected battles vs. the CPU but I didn't feel the game suffered because of a lack of narrative. If you like WWII you get the context and you can fill in the blanks yourself without having a character driven story line. Well, that's it. If you're reading this at all it's because you're interested so pull the trigger. It's a great game 9/10.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												i literally have to give this a "Not Recommended"... why? let me explain.... before? i would have said to buy it, even if you own AS1... sort of a waste of money, but at least no third party multi-player. ( AS1 should have been integrated into steam servers after gamespy closed all servers for all games they supported... but hey, screw that, charge the same players for another game if they want online features )EVEN before i'd say buy this even with it being the EXACT same game as AS1, just ... horribly optimized? somehow my computer can play AS1 no problem. but AS2 dominated my computer....? when they're the same game? no, i don't understand either.but then..... they did the WONDERFUL "Game update 3.112.0" and this has destroyed the game for me. not only does it run EVEN worse on my computer, to the point that any co-op is impossible even with having very fast internet.... but NOW???NOW... you have NO supplies in trucks. no ammo, no anything. oh wait, grenades...? cool? yeah, not really...i loved preparing for an assault, stocking my soldiers up with ammo then heading out. now? you can just put 5 grenades on each person and ... nothing else. i hope you like grenades, because that's all you'll be getting.before, you could unload shells from trucks and make IED's. now, obviously you can't. your troops get a magical resupply of ammo from trucks. even the officer supply drop was ruined. no rifle ammo, no SMG ammo, no MG ammo. your troops can just fire all day and get resupplied from a small paradrop. it makes NO sense and just kills this game for me. the realism is thrown out the window. sir hinkel, as i'm sure anyone that plays AS1 or AS2 knows of... ( if you don't, he makes missions for the German Soldier's Mod, which is amazing as are his missions ) made scripts that resupply your troops with crates / trucks. you can watch the ammo going from the truck / crate, and going into your soldiers inventory. it only resupplies to a set number. so 100 rifle rounds, 300 SMG, 1000 MG....yet the developers somehow did worse than..... a random person using Gem Editor? are you SERIOUS? someone working for free / fun made resupply amazing yet people making LOTS OF MONEY FAIL!?!?!i've held off on this for a few months now. there's no difference..... i bought AS2 ONLY to support this company for making games that have realism. now? NO. ( stupid me, i even bought the Deluxe Edition to support this company )sure, video games are all fantasy, even simulators........but this just destroyed it. this game is not "early access" or alpha, or beta, or ANYTHING else. it's the complete game, and they ruined it for me...yes, yes... i know, huge long rant about one thing, but it offended me this much. i even posted to developers......no response. nothing. this is the only reason i waited for the negative review. in hopes they'd see and fix this horrible thing they've done.because of this, i truly can't recommend that you spend ...any money on this, let alone 29.99$ ( as of this moment )just buy assault squad 1 for a lesser price tag... unless you are REALLY devoted to multi-player and don't want to use third party programs for it.seriously... AS1 is a master-piece and there are a lot of cool scripts and other things you can use to make awesome missions yourself. it's not hard, just need to spend some time on it. i'd be happy to help anyone learn how to use things in Gem Editor, especially for AS1. ( also AS1 will run better on your computer, no matter how good.... or crappy your computer may be )hmmm also, if anyone thinks "only 21.6 hours?" or anything... look at my play time for AS1, 358 hours as of today, and it "may" be my favorite game...ever. that's why i know AS2 is a huge slap in the face to anyone who has played the men of war games. ( if not going even further back with faces of war and even further back... )IF and ONLY IF developers put ammo into trucks and crates again will i give this a positive review, and i'd even suggest you pay 29.99$. it's really not a bad game, seeing as it's close to a direct copy / paste of AS1... just doesn't run as smoothly.LET ME MAKE IED'S AGAIN!!! >;(
