content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Realism - 10The gameplay is much better and realistic than CoH (Tanks can shoot several hundred meters while CoH it's like 25)Graphics - 5CoH 1 looks better than this game. However, you can have much more large scale battles in this than CoH.Sound - 7 Everything kinda sounds the same but the quality is goodLearning Curve - 9 (high)This game is very specific. You can control each individual member or the whole squad at a time. The individual men have a huge array of options. For instance, my Sherman Firefly got destroyed but the .50 cal was intact so once the tank crew abandonded the tank, i told one of the crewmen to grab the .50 cal and then proped it on a wall and began raining hell upon enemy infantry.Overall - 7It's a nice realistic game that's very in depth. If you take the time to learn (3+ hours) you will really enjoy this game. It's not one of those that you can master right after installing.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I consider MOWAS2 to be one of the finest RTS games ever made.1) All the MOW games are pretty similar, and all good.  There are many complaints about how MOWAS2 is the same game as MOWAS, and this is largely true, but not a reason to rate the game down.2) If you've played Company of Heroes, then MOWAS is similar but much more realistic - more like a WW2 simulation.  This makes it a harder game harder to learn, and harder to master but ultimately makes it feel more like you are playing WW2, rather than playing a video game (as with CoH)3) Unfortunately DMS (the devs) are a little sketchy.  For us, the gamers, this means a) the multiplayer is sometimes unreliable and dropped games, lag and connection faliures are too frequent.  It also means you get shady things like MOWAS2 being bacisly the same as MOWAS (see above), and DLC's that are rather obviously designed just to make money and have minimal content.Overall: an outstanding game that is an absolute MUST for any WW2 RTS lover.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Super in-depth, super detailed, super good. Not only can you steal enemy vehicles and guns, you can steal those vehicles' supplies and use them yourself, and then ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL with E and turn the game into a third-person shooter. You can control the inventory of individual infantry down to their damn hats and the bullets in their gun. The environments are almost entirely destructable to a striking degree of detail, which leads to awesome moments like when the bomber you call in for an airstrike is shot down by enemy forces (Yes, you can do that too) and it crashes into a house and knocks it to pieces.The only two complaints that I have about this game are that you can't commandeer everything on the field (Battleships, a German artillery piece in one or two missions, some boats, etc), and that it's far too similar to the original MOWAS - most of the missions are just ported from the older game, and there are very few engine differences - it makes buying the older game feel like a waste of money. I suppose this could stem from the fact that they're all taken from real battles that faction actually won, but I think the base game could stand to have a little more replay value. Still, though, given how much fun it is to play the missions that are there, it doesn't hurt the game much.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												First off, I love the mow series, the first game, assault squad, vietnam, all of them.     Alot of people say this is the exact same game as as1, and really, it is pretty much the same, but many game mechanics were changed, which is good.  They took some really important features out of this game, but they added good mod support, to correct these problems.  I like this game, but it is really similar to as1 with not enough differences, which I dont like, I really only recommend this game if you havent played as1, or are new to the series.       And with the maps, there are VERY good new maps which I absolutely adore, but in some of them, I realized there is no versatility, no game-changing things, and it gets almost robotic, for example, im USA facing Japan, the enemy player sends a kamikazi, sneaks through all of my lines, and then takes out my sherman jumbo.  Im spooked, and then reinforce my lines and everything, but within that few seconds of attempting to strengthen my lines, the enemy player attacks with elite infantry and light tanks, which I cant counter because of my jumbo gone, and I lose the game because of one kamikazi.  I just dont see that anymore in as2, atleast, not often enough, and that a major flaw in this game for me, making me at times really frustrated.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Really the game mechanics are amazing but lack of content is a HUGE hinderence. What this game really needs is a skirmish mode. A REAL skirmish mode because at the moment it only has a few campaign missions disguised as skirmishes on the main menu. Besides that it only has multiplayer and extras. Multiplayer was meh at best for me and I didn't look too throughly into the extras but from what I saw it wasn't worth mentioning.The AI is dreadfully stupid on many occasions from refusing to fire on enemies right in their face to bandaging their own wounds when given the chance to running straight up to a tank to fire a rocket launcher.  You'll spend more time fixing mistakes by a bad AI than actual strategic planning and more often than not losing a few games over AI screw ups. Not once but 5 times have I had my own artillery fire on my soldiers. It's a good game mechanic wise and can give you hours worth of fun but wouldn't recommend buying it at full price as the lack of content is obvious. If there's ever a new Men of War that fixes all these problems and has at least double the content I'll be sure to check it out.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Alright, so, I'm going to revise my Men Of War: Assault Squad 2 review, and I'm going to make it right. When I originally bought the game, I was clueless of the whole Men Of War series and was excited as hell that I had found such a unique RTS to play, and at the time, it was somewhat about £20.00 say about that. When I began to play the game, I had originally hoped that could find my way around the game pretty easily. Indeed, the guides that come with the game really help you, in the long run on getting a grip of the game functions, but over time, I just began to realise why the game got boring. So, enough talk, let's get down to business.The Reasons:1. From what I've begun to see from other Men Of War games, primarily Assault Squad 1, if you will, there is a MASSIVE LACK OF NEW CONTENT. The game feels like a damned Copy-Paste, and by no means does it feel improved. The GUIs don't seem to have been changed too much, with some minor changes, and the admittably better sorting out. The Vehicles appear to be mostly copy-pasted from the first MOWAS to the new MOWAS2, with probably a few new vehicles being added in between, but nothing special at all. The vehicle skins are mostly the same, and very, very, very few have been reskinned. The soldier skins basically are the same ones, and trust me, unless you can make the better skins yourself, they look horribly outdated. The weaponry diversity doesn't seem to exist either, I was hoping for a wider range of firearms, but this was disappointing after a while of seeing this wasn't possible.2. The utter disgrace of an AI. The Unit AI is horrible. Horrible... HORRIBLE! The AI is 100% unable to fend for itself, it does not seek cover, even when free movement is given to it, and if it does, it is a VERY RARE occurrence. AI will also on most terms not fire back at all if an enemy begins to shoot at it, unless you get within some bloody SMG range of the enemy unit for it to involuntarily fire at the enemy attacking it. Infantry will most of the time sit around on their♥♥♥♥♥♥ doing absolutely nothing at all, regardless of the threats around them. They will RARELY EVER throw back an enemy grenade as soon as they see one, but whenever they do, it is probably the only good thing this AI can do, as after throwing it, it decides to jump away from the grenade to avoid getting killed, at least that's smart... somewhat, unless it doesn't throw the grenade at YOUR OWN units.AT Infantry units will probably sit around and do absolutely nothing when they see a tank, and even if they are close enough to engage it, they would rather stare at the tank till it goes by, and then maybe actually consider shooting at it, but most of the time, by the time this would probably happen, they'd be mauled and laying on the floor, squashed by a tank's tracks or MGs.Whenever your SMG Infantry attempt to attack a tank, they will literally run up to the mother-trucker and get themselves squashed, killed, blow up, or even blow themselves up with their own AT Grenade. Your units will on rare occasions decide to use their frag grenades at enemy positions, which is probably another of the actually few smart things the AI does. When told to stay in cover, the AI will NOT switch cover to avoid an incoming vehicle, even if free movement is set on.The tanks probably have the worst AI to date, without a doubt. They will not rotate their armour to hide their weak spots, and they will never attempt to engage an enemy tank properly unless it is in direct sight of the gun. Tanks will never choose to keep their distance against infantry, and will most of the time just approach them, getting within range of their AT Grenades and getting themselves blown up, anyway. AT Guns, Mortars and Artillery Pieces probably don't suffer the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI features, and are actually a bit more intelligent in their operation.Medics do not automatically revive your units, and always require you to do it manually, so this becomes a major bloody headache since you can't pry your eyes off your one squad, while you make a charge on the other side of the map, only to turn back and find all your squad obliterated, lying on the ground like a burnt pancake in the bin.Snipers probably will do something useful, if they're put in the right spot, but can't even attempt to spot enemies for themselves, and when they do, they will most likely just stare and stare till the enemy comes close enough for a standard unscoped rifle kill, which removes the actual bloody use for snipers in the first place.3. The Developers are a big issue with this game. They are lazy, they are money-grabbers and they look down on the whole Community as a bunch of cash-grabs. The DLCs, according the many other players, are barely worth it, and even force you to pay for even more multiplayer features in themselves. They rarely ever fix any issues as regards to Multiplayer Connectivity, as it remains laggy and buggy as hell, shooting players Out Of Sync within the first two minutes of battle. The overall textures they made feel cluttered and the skins of the vehicles are simply copy-paste, showing the utter laziness of the Developers themselves. They never answer the questions of the Community, and never listen to the major bugs or connectivity or AI issues the game has. I'm going to be frank, the Developers can either get off their arses, listen to the Community and fix the game, and make it actually worth playing, or they can overall shut down altogether and not bother making another game, because MOW Origins is just another MOWAS2 Reskin, and MOWAS2 is just a reskin of MOWAS, and making it even worse, Call To Arms (CTA) is just another bloody Modern Warfare Reskin of MOWAS2, with NO improvements in GUI, EVEN MORE bugs, and TWICE AS MANY gameplay issues as MOWAS or MOWAS2 combined. All in all, they never pay attention to their biggest successes, and drown them in a bunch of bugs, failures and deaf ears to the Community.4. You all pretty much can tell that from the past points listed, you'll then look at my play time and say, "Why have you played this game so long then?" Well, I'll cut it simple. The only thing keeping this screw-up of a "game" is the Community with its Workshop and massive amounts of Mods that actually make MOWAS2 better than the way the Developers actually designed it, modifiying the gameplay, units, reskinning them properly, actually making them look aesthetically attractive, making them look badass, and at the same time, improving the qualty of gameplay. Yet MOWAS2 still manages to screw this up by shooting players Out Of Sync, which makes it disappointing to have a great time, on some cases.5. The Multiplayer is a huge recurring vague array of the same simple annoying stuff. It all depends on who is the best at actually storming a position and then continuing to storm it on and on and on and on, and rendering his opponent unable to spawn in any units properly to counter the threat, such that it makes the game ever more boring for the losing side because the winning side will have already spammed about tens of squads and anti-infantry and anti-tank vehicles to make sure you can't even get the slightest edge of hopping back into the fight, forcing you to stare at all you've been playing for during that match, as the countdown timer drops to zero.6. The Singleplayer Missions, whereas some are actually challenging, are very rare in this case. The Singleplayer Missions are a mess, a screw-up, and a huge vague waste of time, especially if they're the typical Skirmish with 11 Strategic Points to capture and having you start from the very beginning, only that after you capture one point, the AI SPAMS THE LIVING HELL OUT OF HIS RESERVES TO TAKE BACK JUST ONE POINT YOU CAPTURED, which makes the Singleplayer a living hell to play, and the fact that you can't pitch in as many units as the AI can sucks.Not worth the money until the game improves. Period. Not worth it at all.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												This game may not be noob friendly, but it sure is fun! Especially with the editor.Any veteran of RTS games is going to find himself just fine, at least in terms of controls and main gameplay features. Diffrences between MoW and its more arcade counterpart *cough* CoH *cough* are quite huge, but the biggest two are realism level and gamemode types. To be fair they are two completly diffrent games. You shouldn't just rush with a T-34 and expect to stay alive thanks to your high healthbar, you have to be carefull at all time, because even an Panzer II can wreck your tank in matters of seconds, if it gets you from the rear.Infantry dies at least 10 times faster and easier than in CoH, it also is 10 times more effective and dangerous. Arty is OP.As far as gameplay goes, there is no base building and unit production, most of the time you have limited resources or you can call units from out of the map, it depends from a gamemode.Graphics are mostly good, there is not much to talk about. Physic engine is great and destruction is top tier.  Optimisation is just brilliant.I strongly recommend this game to any fan of WW2 games and RTS fans. There is also a huge database of mods to choose from, extra nations, even more increased realism, and you can even turn it into a modern RTS with just one mod. 9/10 - Still not perfect.

Posted: February 28, 2015
												This is my review of the Men of War: Assault Squad 2.I bought the game twice (for me and for a friend) and my mind just can't understand how an engine from 2006 could run so bad. The game is barely playable in Multiplayer. For those who have not been playing it before I will say this - imagine a constant lag with micro freezing screens ALL the time. Excuse me, but I run Skyrim much better than this. It lags for 80% of people in multiplayer no matter what your PC configuration is. May be if I take some of NASA's supercomputers I will be able to play a normal game. And the lag is just the beginning - yesteday I won a 1v1 battle only because the the guy against me had several game costing bugs (he can't repair his tank, his crew won't enter the second damaged tank which he managed somehow to repair, and his units got completely stuck several times). Today as always I experienced same thing again and that was the end. I decided to write that and to say don't buy that thing unless they fix it. And believe me I will write here again when the game is playabe again I promise.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Overall, I think Men of War:AS2 is a great game, even if it does have some shortcomings. Looking solely at physics, it is probably one of the most realistic RTS games out there. This isn't Company of Heroes where you can destroy a Tiger by shooting at it enough. Armor is incredibly diverse and I feel fairly accurately portrays the hundreds of vehicles that made WWII interesting. The game does have a lot of vehicles to offer as well as weapons and abilities. It is probably the most immersive RTS game franchise I know. Unfortunately the "realistic" armor does make some countries, like Germany, a little OP, but this is only really an issue in multiplayer when people autolock Germany.A major criticism for this game (which is entirely justified) is how it reused a lot of content from Assault Squad 1 without really adding much. The devs have added a few "free updates" to fix some issues and have improved the graphics. If this is your first time in the Men of War series, this is the definitive version and the one you should get - for those who have already played previous titles, some of the maps are going to feel more than familiar. It is somewhat of a "1.5" sequel rather than "2".The game is challenging but very rewarding. There are so many things you can do that make it stand out from other titles in the genre. You can manage individual soldiers, control their inventories and the weapons they have, and you also have to worry about ammo. You can deman an enemy AT gun or even a tank, and after some quick repairs, use it agains them! There is no more satisfying feeling than seeing "Hull damaged" over an enemy Jagdpanther. All of these features make the game very fun but very difficult when you first start out. The game doesn't hold your hand even though there are (un)helpful tips they give you here and there.The AI, both enemy and friendly is pretty bad, but it is compensated by the manual control feature which allows you to aim and mobilize any solider or vehicle with the arrowkeys and mouse. It is very fun and I can't think of many RTS games that offer that type of engagement. You can even use it to exploit the maximum range by simply aiming at something in front of your target!One final caviat is that the game does crash sometimes in skirmish every so often; it is rare, but when you play 4 hour games with your friends, they are very frustrating when you are halfway to victory. Despite all the issues I listed, this game is still one of my favorites and massively fun to play. Get some friends and play multiplayer skirmish where you can strategically work together to win. With so many vehicles and playability for the Americans, British, Germans, Russians, and Japanese, there are literally hundreds of hours of battles to be had in this game. The steam workshop offers many new maps and modifications that can be added in seconds to enhance your game experience.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												To be fair I haven't played much of this game and I'm geting ready to give it another chance. I happened to catch this game on sale and after reading the rave reviews I bought it. Straight into the game the reviewers were right, it was visually stunning. The problems came with managing the troops, I'll admit I'm more used to Command and Conquer and Age of Empires style RTS games that involve sending units to fight and focusing on grand stragegy. This game offers an incredable (or absurd, depending on perspective) level of micromanaging. It would be a good idea to maybe take notes on hotkeys and instructions before hand, I had a AWFUL time trying to get my guys to use toolkits to repair a damaged vehicle because the controls are so "complex". In all I had to give up on the game because I couldn't get my guys to do what I wanted them to do but I suspect someone with more patience could have a blast with this game.

content:
Posted: January 5
												Great game, facinating scenarios (both in vanilla, dlc, and workshop content), more gritty and realistic than Company of Heroes. Scavenge for weapons, ammo and grenades, sneak up on enemy troops and drop them with throwing knives or silenced weapons, snipe the commander off of a tank's cupola mounted MG, direct artillery to pound entrenched enemies or hidden field guns, track a deadly tank destroyer so you can flank it, repair your own tanks damaged main gun so you can bring it back into the fight. syphon fuel out of derelict vehicles to keep your machines running, detect mines, lay down barbed wire, chuck a bundle of dynamite into a building the enemy has dug into to level it, cover your squads and vehicles advances and retreats with smoke grenades.... there is SO much you can do, it will keep you coming back for more. Every replay is different.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Men of War is an amazing game. While not terribly similar to a conventional rts, this is what makes the game unique and interesting. Instead of researching technologies or building barracks, Men of War allows you to get reinforcements through "mp", which is steadily gained no moatter what. The rate can be improved by capturing "strategic points" which are usually marked by a flag. This will show the controlling team's flag as well. Soldiers then run from outside the battlefield into a team's spawn, and then you have reinforcements. Likewise, actual gameplay mechanics diverge from standard rts. The focus moves away from the types of units used and towards what you actually do with them. For example, you can move units into cover and buildings, allowing them to gain protection in certain directions respective to where you put them. Medics can also revive fallen units for a certain time, although (and correct me if I'm wrong) I believe there is a certain number of times a medic can revive a soldier before the soldier stays dead. The game plays like a shooter, except that instead of controlling one soldier you control an army, if that makes sense. I love it, and it is a refreshing break from the standard rts model and its various spinoffs.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2016
												This game may not be noob friendly, but it sure is fun! Especially with the editor.Any veteran of RTS games is going to find himself just fine, at least in terms of controls and main gameplay features. Diffrences between MoW and its more arcade counterpart *cough* CoH *cough* are quite huge, but the biggest two are realism level and gamemode types. To be fair they are two completly diffrent games. You shouldn't just rush with a T-34 and expect to stay alive thanks to your high healthbar, you have to be carefull at all time, because even an Panzer II can wreck your tank in matters of seconds, if it gets you from the rear.Infantry dies at least 10 times faster and easier than in CoH, it also is 10 times more effective and dangerous. Arty is OP.As far as gameplay goes, there is no base building and unit production, most of the time you have limited resources or you can call units from out of the map, it depends from a gamemode.Graphics are mostly good, there is not much to talk about. Physic engine is great and destruction is top tier.  Optimisation is just brilliant.I strongly recommend this game to any fan of WW2 games and RTS fans. There is also a huge database of mods to choose from, extra nations, even more increased realism, and you can even turn it into a modern RTS with just one mod. 9/10 - Still not perfect.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												The game is very fun.  The graphics are pretty decent and you can see substantially further on the map as compared to Company of Heroes 2.  It takes awhile to learn the game and get proficient at it, but it is worth the time.Items that could be improved include:-The AT grenades are far too overpowered.  They tend to do more damage to tanks than AT guns and other tanks.  An AT grenade in this game can destroy a heavy tank after the tank has taken numerous shots from AT guns or other tanks.  It is frustrating to lose a tank to an AT grenade in this game.  Not to mention that it is very unrealistic that standard infantry carry around heavy AT grenades and are able to run through fields and throw them onto a tank without getting mowed down first.  It is one thing to have a special unit that carries AT grenades but this game puts them on standard infantry.  That part is pretty ridiculous but the rest of the game is quite good.-Wish there were more players playing multiplayer.  Sometimes it takes awhile to get a game going.-The AT guns appear to be quite underpowered.  A tank can generally shoot accross the field and take out the AT gun while the AT gun is shooting the tank.  This is a minor issue as you can avoid it by ordering tanks and other items rather than AT guns.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
 Men of War: Assault Squad 2 REVIEW Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is the near identical sequel to Men of War: Assault Squad with many minor changes.If you have played a Men of War game before then you would know how it plays out. Lots of micromanagement. Can get annoying and frustrating at times with placement of units, supplying units with ammunition, etc. Typical Men of War fun. There are lots of tanks, cars, artillery, weapons and other stuff. The game also has realistic armour penetration (don't trust me on this - I am no expert!) for vehicles. The games graphics are identical to the previous titles apart from a few new minor graphical options. The A.I. is still also the same which is running around the battlefield in a endless search & destroy of you. Kinda mindless A.I. but they can pull a few tricks from it's sleeve sometimes. They are better at suicide charges or static defences.There are four factions just like the previous games: Japan, Commonwealth, Germany and USA.Still has the absolutely beautiful destruction physics from the previous games - So satisfying to see buildings crumble in so many different ways. Comes with a level editor. Overall I don't recommend this game if you own previous titles because I just feel like this is the same game with only minor changes. Get it when it's like 50% off or something.Score: 5/10 - Not worth the $30 I spent.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Men of War: Assault Squad 2 (although quite fun and challenging) is an unfurbished experience. First of all, I'll start with my main gripe with this game, which is the terrible A.I. My soldiers would make the dumbest ♥♥♥♥ing mistakes regularly, they would stop running to cover to shoot at a tank (thus getting blown up), randomly drop to the ground in danger (making them get killed), not fire from buildings when the target is clear from the window (making them get shot and killed) and they would always stop at a certain distance from the spawn once they enter the fray (letting their comrades in the front get killed). The only thing that I like in this game is the immense scale. Unlike the other rts ww2 game I have in my library (something company?) this lacks any sort of unit cap, letting you control hundreds of units at once. In short, this game is a flawed mess. Buyer beware.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Men of War Assault Squad 2 has some interesting concepts compaired to something like, Company of heroes 1 or 2. That tanks healthbars have been replaced with a armor penetration system. Soldiers can't run in the open in front of a machine gun without dying. The game has a direct control feature for soldiers and vehicles that allows you to aim and move that person or vehicle.The games UI and Pathmaking has some problems. This shines the most in close quarter combat with infantry. The game also has a strong modsupport to spice up the game even more.All in all this game is a bit advanced for the new player, but besides that and a few minor issues, it's great

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												ProsI have about 20 hours, on/offline playing MoWAS2. There's a learning curve equal to the number of individual players you control, however, am thinking this may be the best game yet, for me. I did not have first game so no disappointments over refreshed previous games. My machine is getting on in years but MoWAS2 plays great - even if I am defeated a great deal. Very challenging and No Thanks to cheat codes (so far).Former best games for me since created were Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Prypriat (after years playing still have hard time spelling it but loved playing it on all levels to master) soso about Clear Sky.  Love MoWAS2 ... very challenging and very intense, alikened to herding 60 cats through a fish factory. Let your guard down for an instant, even at 90% accomplished and truly massive enemy counterattacks can overwhelm and defeat you, so remain focused on the V for Victory symbol and Objectives. Also great idea others wrote, (Thanks) PAUSE game at beginning to scan all terrain - this intel usually makes a difference to outcomes.ConsOnly con is finding a gaming manual or online written heirachy explaining various armor and soldiers features. Regards

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5
												Great game, facinating scenarios (both in vanilla, dlc, and workshop content), more gritty and realistic than Company of Heroes. Scavenge for weapons, ammo and grenades, sneak up on enemy troops and drop them with throwing knives or silenced weapons, snipe the commander off of a tank's cupola mounted MG, direct artillery to pound entrenched enemies or hidden field guns, track a deadly tank destroyer so you can flank it, repair your own tanks damaged main gun so you can bring it back into the fight. syphon fuel out of derelict vehicles to keep your machines running, detect mines, lay down barbed wire, chuck a bundle of dynamite into a building the enemy has dug into to level it, cover your squads and vehicles advances and retreats with smoke grenades.... there is SO much you can do, it will keep you coming back for more. Every replay is different.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I have played Men Of War since the first release and Faces Of War alongside heroes of world war 2 and to be honest this is a complete disappointing remake of old crap they didn't include in other games. They basically spent the time adding more units which should of been in the first games. Same missions for each faction and same objectives and map layout just different skins and poor voiceovers. The devs really are pushing money on this series to make other games by promising new exciting additions which are pointless and should be part of the game initially anyways. Multiplayer.... full of people who spend all day hiding tanks in the corner of the map to gain brownie points to look good on the rankking system, a bit like call of duty boosting to be quite frank. I wonder when Men Of War 3 will be out, another assault squad remake of the first game which is technically the second but will be the third???I actually managed to work my way up in emails through the company of the creators person by person I got to the top....who didnt reply....This game was good until after the first one....maybe they should of stopped there?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Even though I haven't played much, I think I have seen enough of the game to give an honest review. The graphics are pretty good, the destructibility can be impressive, there are a ton of missions and maps and they seem to be well designed, all of the major factions from WW2 are available to play with, and there is a vast range of vehicles and equipment available to the player. The only problems I would say is the controls, AI, and bugs. There are a ton of controls, some of which are a little wonky like the unit movement function, but I guess it comes with the fact that there are so many functions to use in game. The more serious problem is the AI. The AI don't even respond to your commands half the time, and they sometimes won't respond to an enemy that is shooting at you from literally 5 ft away. And sometimes one of your men will move to a different position without your command. This is particularly a problem in trenches, where sometimes one of your men will jump out of your trench without your command. And the bugs can be irritating at times, like the occasional crashing and framerate problems. Overall, I don't think it's worth the full price just because of the AI and bugs I mentioned above, but on a sale I would recommend getting the complete edition.

The constant barrage of bugs is simply too much, from units somehow dying on their own to them getting stuck and constantly needing to issue new orders or very often even having to take the controls yourself to guide them out, the campaign is a joke, its just the same missions for each faction packaged a little different, without mods the game would die, and sometimes it does, when useless updates are issued, making you have to wait for the mods to also be updated.

												Serious improvement in single-player land if you use Windows 10 64bit.You might want to turn down shadows and special effects (shadows still give your system a beating and effects (explosion and such) give me hiccups).But all in all, I'm playing @ maxed settings (exept those 2).If you are a fan of squad level RTS, without basebuilding in a WW2 settings, I can surely recommend this.Best in it's genreToday, 22-6-2016 (06/22/2016), another 1GB patch was delivered.That is some support!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												So i bought the first game, and as much as i wanted to like it, it was a frustrating game to play. It seemed unbalanced, reloading of weapons was a pain, ai was very stupid. The idea was there but execution was poor.So i have been hovering for an age looking into this title, seeing if they fixed the problems i found so annoying in the first. The other day i couldnt resist so i bought it. For me its changed this game into a fun addictive ww2 strategy sim. I absolutly love it now. All those issues above seemed to be fixed, i can play on normal ai without getting squads of tanks sent at me. I had agreat round with the AI at "overlord" the battle, back n forth waged for hours. Relaoding is miles easier,, Ai squad, while not 100% perfect behave much better, now they will toss back grenades, or even use them efficiently. Its a great game, although what at a glance doesnt seem much different for me is a better polished version of the first. Maybe it doesnt deserve its own title but more of an upgrade. Find it cheaper than a tenner then go for itMay favorite ww2  tactical rts without the base building.COH who?8/10
